bibl.title: Letter from the saint Papa to the queen Helena

div.p: This text is a born-digital edition of the Letter from the saint Papa to the >queen Helena. The letter is part of a corpus of eight letters representing the correspondence of Papa bar Aggai, early 4th-century bishop of Seleucia, with some exponents of the western political and religious power. Beside the Letter from the saint Papa to the queen Helena, the corpus includes: a letter from Eusebius of Rome to Papa, a letter from Judah Kyriakos bishop of Jerusalem to Papa, a letter of the Empress Helena to Papa, a letter from Jacob bishop of Nisibis to Papa, a letter from Ephrem to Papa, a letter from Papa to the citizens of Nisibis, the letter sent by the Western Fathers on the illegal removal of Papa.
This edition is based on the following manuscript witnesses:
Rome, Vatican Library, Borg. Sir. 82, f. 115v-116r; 109v (B);
Trichur, Chaldean Syrian Church, APSTCH THRI 65, f. 48v-49r (A) (the manuscript has been digitized, and it can be viewed here);
Baghdad, Chaldean Catholic Church. Patriarchate of Baghdad 377, f. 13v/14v (C) (the manuscript has been digitized, and it can be viewed here).
This text has never been published in any prior edition.
This edition should not be considered as definitive but as a still in-progress material.

There is an old German translation of the entire corpus (based on the Syriac text preserved in ms Borg. Sir. 82) in O. Braun, "Der Briefwechsel des Katholikos Papa von Seleucia. Ein Beitrag zur Geschichte der ostsyrischen Kirche im vierten Jahrhundert", Zeitschrift für katholische Theologie 18 (1894), pp. 163-182, 546-565.
An English translation is provided along with the Syriac text.
This edition is an outcome of the Marie Skłodowska-Curie Global Fellowship 2022 – Project "ForM - FORGED MEMORIES: the Church of Late Antique Iran and the West", funded by the European Commission.

From the saint Papa to the queen Helena
To the blessed mother, the believing queen Helena, Papa servant of Jesus and worshipper and devotee of His cross. Peace.

My lady queen, these [things] that you seek from us, our mental faculties are not sufficient to reach [an idea of] what is useful and [then] to write to you, because the Christians of our region glorify themselves in poverty, chains and in [their] various sufferings. And a small hut is large as our house of prayer; and [this] not because we are lazy and negligent concerning the buildings, but so that the jealousy of the pagans does not act wickedly against us because of the greatness [of our] buildings; the catechizing of Christianity is absent because of the danger of persecutions raised against us. And we are compelled to keep safe the liturgical office that you sent to us, but we are afraid to offer it openly and to perform the office according to its rite, lest it is taken away from us with pretexts. And it is not only the pagans that we fear, but also the Jews and Marcionites, who, as they were oppressed in your jurisdiction from the authority of your kingdom, flee in this region of ours, and they came here before your decree. They have entirely increased enmity, and they hated us. And every time, they set against us clear pretexts, and they accuse us in the secular tribunals. We briefly delineated to your majesty these things about us – in order to write and let you know, as one who is sick with a disease [informs] his physician of his pain and his illness; and when the wise physician see if there is hope
M1: medicine for him, he knows the cure that is good for him – those [things] that are put under your authority in our regions. And the authority, the wisdom, the arm, the heroism and the victory of Christ [are] with you. It is right for you to examine according to your knowledge and to understand
C: to (judge)/manage; M1: to be directed according to your authority. Inform us who are foreigners what you think you could do to help. My lady, we receive the good will of your majesty as a gift greater than building churches. And also in you we glorify God Lord Christ, and with supplications, fervent prayer
A: thanksgiving, love and with the fear that comes from the anxiety of the heart, we offer a prayer for you in the Church of God; and especially me, the poor and sinner Papa, and the least of all the disciples of Christ, with sad tears I supplicate the Lord to command (sic
Probably mistaken reading for: "to stretch out") his right hand upon you, and to command to his holy angels to guard you in all your ways (cf. Ps 91 [90], 11), and as a shepherd who carries his lambs and his sheep on his shoulders, so you will carry the sons of the Church on the shoulders of your authority. And all the believers, in the institution of your regality, will take courage and in you will be strengthened all the Christians who inhabits the habitable world. A salutation, through a writing of my own hand, I, Papa, send to your believing majesty. May the Cross of our Savior Christ, through which your majesty has been exalted and became great, guard the whole church that is under the heaven. Amen.
